cards.front:
At what age does separation anxiety typically peak in infants and small children?

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: 10 to 18 months

cards.front:
Breathing is often more difficult in older adults because the:

(See Older Adults (61 Years and Older))
cards.back: elasticity of the lungs decreases.

cards.front:
In contrast to secure attachment, anxious-avoidant attachment occurs when a child:

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding middle adults is correct?

(See Middle Adults (41 to 60 Years))
cards.back: Cardiovascular health becomes an issue in this age group, as does the greater incidence of cancer.

cards.front:
Which of the following is an anatomic difference between children and adults?

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: An infant’s tongue is proportionately larger than an adult’s tongue.

cards.front:
Which of the following are noticeable characteristics of a 9-month-old infant?

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: Places objects in the mouth, pulls himself or herself up

cards.front:
Factors that contribute to a decline in the vital capacity of an elderly patient include all of the following, except:

(See Older Adults (61 Years and Older))
cards.back: increased surface area available for air exchange.

cards.front:
Which of the following is not a common factor that would affect a 75-year-old patient’s vital signs?

(See Older Adults (61 Years and Older))
cards.back: Increased weight

cards.front:
Age-related changes in the renal system result in:

(See Older Adults (61 Years and Older))
cards.back: a decreased ability to clear wastes from the body and a decreased ability to conserve fluids when needed.

cards.front:
In preconventional reasoning, children:

(See School-Age Children (6 to 12 Years))
cards.back: act almost purely to avoid punishment and to get what they want.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding an infant’s vital signs is correct?

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: An infant’s normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler’s normal body temperature.

cards.front:
You are assessing a 13-month-old female who is running a fever and has been vomiting. While you are performing your physical examination on this child, you will most likely find that she:

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.

cards.front:
An infant or small child’s airway can be occluded if it is overextended or overflexed because:

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: the occiput is proportionately large and the trachea is flexible.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding toddlers and preschoolers is correct?

(See Toddlers (1 to 3 Years) and Preschoolers (3 to 6 Years))
cards.back: Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.

cards.front:
In contrast to secure attachment, anxious-avoidant attachment occurs when a child:

(See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year))
cards.back: shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.

cards.front:
The pulse rate of a child from ages 6 to 12 years is approximately:

(See Introduction)
cards.back: 70 to 120 beats/min.

cards.front:
The average pulse rate of persons between 19 and 40 years of age is typically:

(See Early Adults (19 to 40 Years))
cards.back: 70 beats/min.

cards.front:
The human body should be functioning at its optimal level between the ages of:

(See Early Adults (19 to 40 Years))
cards.back: 19 and 25 years.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding age-related changes in the nervous system is correct?

(See Older Adults (61 Years and Older))
cards.back: Interconnections between brain cells often prevent a loss of knowledge or skill, despite a loss of neurons.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding psychosocial development in the adolescent age group is correct?

(See Adolescents (12 to 18 Years))
cards.back: Antisocial behavior and peer pressure peak around 14 to 16 years of age.
